noun.description: A young child's bed with barred or latticed sides.
A translation of a text for use by students, especially in a surreptitious way.
examples: an English crib of Caesar's Gallic Wars

noun.description: A heavy timber framework used in foundations for a building or to line a mine shaft.

verb.description: Copy (another person's work) illicitly or without acknowledgment.
examples: he was doing an exam and didn't want anybody to crib the answers from him
he often cribbed from other researchers
he had been so cabined, cribbed, and confined by office

origin: Old English (in the sense manger), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch krib, kribbe and German Krippe.
